SetFrequency(Direction, uint, double, IDictionary<string, string>)

Set the center frequency of the chain.

  • For RX, this specifies the down-conversion frequency.
  • For TX, this specifies the up-conversion frequency.

When no args are provided, setFrequency() will tune the "RF" component as close as possible to the requested center frequency. Tuning inaccuracies will be compensated for with the "BB" component.

The args can be used to augment the tuning algorithm.

  • Use "OFFSET" to specify an "RF" tuning offset, usually with the intention of moving the LO out of the passband. The offset will be compensated for using the "BB" component.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and a frequency in Hz as the value (any format) to enforce a specific frequency. The other components will be tuned with compensation to achieve the specified overall frequency.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and the value "IGNORE" so that the tuning algorithm will avoid altering the component.
  • Vendor specific implementations can also use the same args to augment tuning in other ways such as specifying fractional vs integer N tuning.
Declaration
public void SetFrequency(Direction direction, uint channel, double frequency, IDictionary<string, string> args)
Parameters
Type Name Description
Direction direction

The channel direction (RX or TX)
uint channel

An available channel on the device
double frequency

The center frequency in Hz
IDictionary<string, string> args

Optional tuner arguments

SetFrequency(Direction, uint, double, string)

Set the center frequency of the chain.

  • For RX, this specifies the down-conversion frequency.
  • For TX, this specifies the up-conversion frequency.

When no args are provided, setFrequency() will tune the "RF" component as close as possible to the requested center frequency. Tuning inaccuracies will be compensated for with the "BB" component.

The args can be used to augment the tuning algorithm.

  • Use "OFFSET" to specify an "RF" tuning offset, usually with the intention of moving the LO out of the passband. The offset will be compensated for using the "BB" component.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and a frequency in Hz as the value (any format) to enforce a specific frequency. The other components will be tuned with compensation to achieve the specified overall frequency.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and the value "IGNORE" so that the tuning algorithm will avoid altering the component.
  • Vendor specific implementations can also use the same args to augment tuning in other ways such as specifying fractional vs integer N tuning.
Declaration
public void SetFrequency(Direction direction, uint channel, double frequency, string args = "")
Parameters
Type Name Description
Direction direction

The channel direction (RX or TX)
uint channel

An available channel on the device
double frequency

The center frequency in Hz
string args

Optional tuner arguments

SetFrequency(Direction, uint, string, double, IDictionary<string, string>)

Tune the center frequency of the specified element.

  • For RX, this specifies the down-conversion frequency.
  • For TX, this specifies the up-conversion frequency.

When no args are provided, setFrequency() will tune the "RF" component as close as possible to the requested center frequency. Tuning inaccuracies will be compensated for with the "BB" component.

The args can be used to augment the tuning algorithm.

  • Use "OFFSET" to specify an "RF" tuning offset, usually with the intention of moving the LO out of the passband. The offset will be compensated for using the "BB" component.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and a frequency in Hz as the value (any format) to enforce a specific frequency. The other components will be tuned with compensation to achieve the specified overall frequency.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and the value "IGNORE" so that the tuning algorithm will avoid altering the component.
  • Vendor specific implementations can also use the same args to augment tuning in other ways such as specifying fractional vs integer N tuning.

uint channel

An available channel on the device

The name of a tunable element
double frequency

  • For RX, this specifies the down-conversion frequency.
  • For TX, this specifies the up-conversion frequency.

When no args are provided, setFrequency() will tune the "RF" component as close as possible to the requested center frequency. Tuning inaccuracies will be compensated for with the "BB" component.

The args can be used to augment the tuning algorithm.

  • Use "OFFSET" to specify an "RF" tuning offset, usually with the intention of moving the LO out of the passband. The offset will be compensated for using the "BB" component.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and a frequency in Hz as the value (any format) to enforce a specific frequency. The other components will be tuned with compensation to achieve the specified overall frequency.
  • Use the name of a component for the key and the value "IGNORE" so that the tuning algorithm will avoid altering the component.

SetupRxStream(string, uint[], IDictionary<string, string>)

Initialize a receive stream given a list of channels and stream arguments.

The implementation may change switches or power-up components. All stream API calls should be usable with the new stream object after setupStream() is complete, regardless of the activity state.

The API allows any number of simultaneous TX and RX streams, but many dual-channel devices are limited to one stream in each direction, using either one or both channels. This call will throw an exception if an unsupported combination is requested, or if a requested channel in this direction is already in use by another stream.

When multiple channels are added to a stream, they are typically expected to have the same sample rate. See SetSampleRate().

Declaration
public RxStream SetupRxStream(string format, uint[] channels, IDictionary<string, string> kwargs)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string format

The stream's sample type (see StreamFormat).
uint[] channels

A list of channels to use for the stream.
IDictionary<string, string> kwargs
Returns
Type Description
RxStream

A receive stream created with the given settings.

The returned stream is not required to have internal locking, and may not be used concurrently from multiple threads.

SetupRxStream(string, uint[], string)

Initialize a receive stream given a list of channels and stream arguments.

The implementation may change switches or power-up components. All stream API calls should be usable with the new stream object after setupStream() is complete, regardless of the activity state.

The API allows any number of simultaneous TX and RX streams, but many dual-channel devices are limited to one stream in each direction, using either one or both channels. This call will throw an exception if an unsupported combination is requested, or if a requested channel in this direction is already in use by another stream.

When multiple channels are added to a stream, they are typically expected to have the same sample rate. See SetSampleRate().

Declaration

Parameters
Type Name Description
string format

The stream's sample type (see StreamFormat).
uint[] channels

A list of channels to use for the stream.
string args

Stream arguments or empty for defaults (markup format: "keyA=valA, keyB=valB").
Returns
Type Description
RxStream

A receive stream created with the given settings.

The returned stream is not required to have internal locking, and may not be used concurrently from multiple threads.

TransactSPI(int, uint, uint)

Perform a SPI transaction and return the result.

It's up to the implementation to set the clock rate, and read edge, and the write edge of the SPI core. SPI slaves without a readback pin will return 0.

If the device contains multiple SPI masters, the address bits can encode which master.

Declaration
public uint TransactSPI(int addr, uint data, uint numBits)
Parameters
Type Name Description
int addr

An address of an available SPI slave
uint data

The SPI data, numBits-1 is first out
uint numBits

The number of bits to clock out
Returns
Type Description
uint

The readback data, numBits-1 is first in

WriteSetting<T>(Direction, uint, string, T)

Write an arbitrary channel setting on the device, typecasted from the given type.

For bools and primitive numeric types, SoapySDR's internal type conversion is used. Otherwise, the value of the input's ToString() will be passed in.
